overall_summary: The reasoning trajectory demonstrates a methodical approach to time-series forecasting with limited data (96 hourly points). It begins by assessing data completeness and seasonality patterns, evaluates multiple modeling options (SARIMA, Exponential Smoothing), and ultimately selects a simple averaging method due to data constraints. The approach is pragmatic, emphasizing baseline methods when faced with insufficient data for complex models, while carefully considering seasonality and potential day-of-week effects.
key_insights: Short data horizons (4 days) necessitate simplified approaches over complex models like SARIMA
Negative values preclude multiplicative seasonality models
Day-of-week patterns require more data than available for reliable modeling
Hourly averaging provides a viable baseline for short-term forecasts
Data rounding precision (3 decimals) must match input specifications
complexity_analysis: Moderately complex initial analysis with practical simplification. Includes thorough evaluation of modeling alternatives, data pattern recognition, and consideration of real-world constraints, but ultimately implements a straightforward heuristic method due to data limitations.
